comment: Gelfand plays openings which are ideal for an aggressive player, but he isn't a wild-eyed tactician; he's a planner and classical positional player.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5
comment: White's aim is to open the e-file or to "break" Black's pawn structure. The immediate threat of e5-e6 is reminiscent of an Alekhine's Defense position. If White doesn't play e4-e5 immediately then Black might get sufficient control of e5 to keep White boxed-in on the light squares.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6
comment: Black tries to keep control of e5 to prevent White from playing g2-g4 followed by Nf3-e5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6
comment: While Black gets good piece activity the poor pawn structure must make Gelfand a little nervous.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O
comment: Playing a Nh4 or Nd4 to add pressure to the pin on Nf3 would be desirable, but White can step out of the pin with Qd1-e1. Black has to do more, so he castles and prepares to bring more forces into play.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4
comment: Though White needs to clear the way for Bc1 to develop it's a little odd to see him weaken Nf3 this way. Does he intend to move Bc1 and then play Ne4-d2 to re-establish the defense of Nf3, or is g2-g4 still being considered?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1
comment: White's pawn structure is quite modest, but from that his pieces might spring forward. Only the pin on Nf3 is troublesome.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8
comment: It appears Black might want to play ...e6-e5 to secure control of d4 and f4, but he might also have in mind to play ...Bd6-f8 to keep the bishop on the board.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3
comment: So, this is the idea behind Nd2-e4. Black has to either retreat and give up on the pin on Nf3 or give up one of the bishops for a knight. He could trade off Bd6  (13...Bxg3 14. fxg3) or Bh5 (13...Bxf3 14. Qxf3) .

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6
comment: Apparently he didn't see any immediate value to trading, so he keeps the two bishops in hopes of some future time when they'll be especially valuable.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7
comment: I don't understand giving up Pc5 in this situation. What plan does Black follow which demands the bishop be at c7 rather than d6 or f8?

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5
comment: Black threatens to open the position, possibly with ...f7-f5, ...e5-e4, before White can complete his development.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3
comment: White, apparently, is not terribly impressed and simply uses Pa3 to oppose Nd5 and possibly to support b2-b4, whereby Nc5 is defended and Bc1-b2 becomes available.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4
comment: The resulting weakness at d4 seems trivial. The more important thing is to get rid of Nd5, so Bc1 can be developed to a useful square.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2
comment: just keeping Pd4 defended, however awkward it may be

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6
comment: This clearly indicates he intends to get rid of Ne5 with his rook, hoping to retain control of f4 with Qd6 & Bc7.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3
comment: Black has reached an impasse. His queen and rooks and even Bc7 are blocked severely on dark squares by Pd4 & Ne5.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7
comment: White keeps Pd4 and Be3 to maintain control of the central dark squares.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5
comment: White wins one exchange and now threatens two more! This looks like a catastrophe for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3
comment: saving one exchange and gaining time to save the other

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8
comment: At this moment it appears Black has made the necessary breakthrough. Be5 is a powerhouse and Rd3 is also very good.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5
comment: White seems satisfied to repeat the position. Black may think he has the better of it, so he tries for more. I don't think that's a wise decision.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2
comment: This move is what Black allowed when he refused to repeat the position and played 29...Re7. White now threatens Nc5xe4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2 Bd6 32. b4 Kf7 33. Bc3 e3 34. Bd4 Bxc5 35. Bxc5 Re5 36. fxe3 f3 37. gxf3 Bxf3
comment: White is better on the queen-side and now has a share of the center under control (Bc5 & Pe3 work together well) , but Kg1 is a little exposed, so he should improve that before proceeding with his strengths.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2 Bd6 32. b4 Kf7 33. Bc3 e3 34. Bd4 Bxc5 35. Bxc5 Re5 36. fxe3 f3 37. gxf3 Bxf3 38. Kh2 Be4 39. Rb2 Rh5 40. Rf1
comment: activating the piece, preventing ...Nf6-g4+ and in place to defend Ph3

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2 Bd6 32. b4 Kf7 33. Bc3 e3 34. Bd4 Bxc5 35. Bxc5 Re5 36. fxe3 f3 37. gxf3 Bxf3 38. Kh2 Be4 39. Rb2 Rh5 40. Rf1 a6 41. Bd4 Bf5
comment: Black does all he can to avoid too many exchanges; he's also threatening Ph3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2 Bd6 32. b4 Kf7 33. Bc3 e3 34. Bd4 Bxc5 35. Bxc5 Re5 36. fxe3 f3 37. gxf3 Bxf3 38. Kh2 Be4 39. Rb2 Rh5 40. Rf1 a6 41. Bd4 Bf5 42. Rf3 Ne4 43. b5 axb5 44. cxb5 cxb5 45. Rxb5
comment: How convenient for White, to end these exchanges by pinning Bf5!

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 d6 4. Bxc6+ bxc6 5. O-O Bg4 6. h3 Bh5 7. e5 e6 8. exd6 Bxd6 9. d3 Ne7 10. Nbd2 O-O 11. Ne4 Nd5 12. Re1 Re8 13. Ng3 Bg6 14. Ne4 Bc7 15. Nxc5 e5 16. a3 f5 17. c4 Nf6 18. d4 e4 19. Ne5 Bh5 20. Qd2 Qd6 21. Qc3 Rad8 22. Be3 Rxe5 23. Nb7 Qf8 24. dxe5 Rd3 25. Qb4 Bxe5 26. Qxf8+ Kxf8 27. Nc5 Rd6 28. Nb7 Rd7 29. Nc5 Re7 30. Rab1 f4 31. Bd2 Bd6 32. b4 Kf7 33. Bc3 e3 34. Bd4 Bxc5 35. Bxc5 Re5 36. fxe3 f3 37. gxf3 Bxf3 38. Kh2 Be4 39. Rb2 Rh5 40. Rf1 a6 41. Bd4 Bf5 42. Rf3 Ne4 43. b5 axb5 44. cxb5 cxb5 45. Rxb5 g6 46. a4 Nd2 47. Rf4 Rxh3+ 48. Kg2 Rh5 49. a5 Ke6
comment: unpinning Bf5 and threatening ...Bh3+ or ...Be4+ to win Rb5
